L1.brief_rationale: The most fundamental concept in metaphysics; concerns what it means for something to be or to exist.
The totality of what exists; distinguishing what is real from what is merely apparent or imaginary.
The dimension along which events occur in sequence; central to debates about change, persistence, and causation.
The boundless three-dimensional extent in which objects have position and direction; fundamental to metaphysical accounts of the physical world.
The relationship between causes and effects; one of the central structural features of reality investigated by metaphysics.
The seat of consciousness, thought, and experience; focal point of debates about substance dualism and physicalism.
What makes something the same thing over time or across possible situations; foundational to personal identity debates.
The process by which things come to have properties they previously lacked; raises puzzles about persistence and continuity.
The capacity to make choices unconstrained by prior causes; central to debates about determinism and moral responsibility.
A non-physical essence traditionally held to constitute personal identity; historically significant in metaphysics of mind.
The concept of a supreme being whose existence, nature, and relation to the world are perennial metaphysical questions.
Physical stuff that constitutes the observable world; core concept in debates about the nature of substance.
Mathematical entities whose ontological status—abstract or concrete—is a foundational question in metaphysics of mathematics.

L2.brief_rationale: The branch of metaphysics concerned with the nature and structure of being and what kinds of things exist.
The thesis that every event is necessitated by prior causes and the laws of nature; central to free will debates.
The metaphysical category of independently existing things that bear properties; contrasts with bundle theory.
Attributes or qualities that objects possess; their nature and ontological status is debated between realists and nominalists.
David Lewis's view that all possible worlds are equally real concrete entities; a radical position in modal metaphysics.
A complete way the world could have been; used to analyze modal claims about necessity and possibility.
The view that mind and body are distinct kinds of substance; associated with Descartes and opposed to physicalism.
The thesis that everything that exists is physical or supervenes on the physical; the dominant metaphysical framework in contemporary philosophy.
Objects that lack spatiotemporal location, such as numbers and propositions; their existence is contested by nominalists.
The necessary features that make a thing what it is; central to debates about de re modality and natural kinds.
The distinction between what must be the case and what merely happens to be the case; fundamental to modal metaphysics.
A dependency relation whereby higher-level facts cannot differ without lower-level facts differing; used to articulate physicalism.
The view that only particular concrete things exist and that universals or abstract objects have no independent existence.

L3.brief_rationale: The debate over whether universals—properties shared by multiple particulars—exist independently, in things, or only as names.
The question of what constitutes the continuity of a person through time; debated in terms of psychological and physical continuity.
The view that free will and determinism are compatible; typically analyzes free will in terms of acting on one's own reasons without compulsion.
The formal study of part-whole relations; raises questions about composition, simples, and what constitutes a genuine object.
The view that past, present, and future entities all equally exist; the 'block universe' view opposed to presentism.
The view that only present entities exist; contrasts with eternalism and raises puzzles about cross-temporal relations.
The view that objects are nothing more than bundles of properties, with no underlying bare particular or substrate.
The principle that every physical effect has a sufficient physical cause; a key premise in arguments for physicalism over dualism.
The arising of novel properties at higher levels of organization that cannot be straightforwardly reduced to lower-level properties.
Categories that carve nature at its joints, such as chemical elements; their metaphysical status bears on essentialism and modality.
Regularities governing the physical world; debated between Humean regularity theorists and necessitarians about their ontological status.
The view that properties are particular, non-repeatable instances (tropes) rather than universals shared across objects.

L4.brief_rationale: A non-causal dependence relation whereby one fact holds in virtue of another; central to contemporary debates about metaphysical structure.
The view that truths require entities in the world that make them true; raises questions about what exists to ground negative and modal truths.
The view that objects persist through time by having distinct temporal parts; contrasts with endurantism about persistence.
The view that objects persist through time by being wholly present at each moment; raises puzzles about change in properties.
The view that individuals have a primitive 'thisness' distinct from their qualitative properties; relevant to questions of transworld identity.
The view that only structural relations are fundamental and objects are derivative; a radical position in philosophy of physics.
David Lewis's thesis that all facts supervene on the spatiotemporal distribution of local intrinsic qualities; grounds his regularity theory of laws.
The view that some contradictions are true; challenges the law of non-contradiction and has implications for metaphysics and logic.
The view that composite objects do not exist; only simples are real, with apparent composites being mere fictions or descriptions.
Lewis's account of de re modal claims in terms of counterparts in other possible worlds rather than transworld identity of individuals.
A discrete approach to quantum gravity proposing that spacetime is fundamentally a partially ordered set of causal relations between events.
Jonathan Schaffer's view that the whole universe is the one fundamental entity and all proper parts exist only as derivative; contrasts with pluralism.
